arm_group.description: Cross-over design, half of the subject will receive lean seafood in study period I and the other half in study period II
Cross-over design, half of the subject will receive meat, egg, milk in study period I and the other half in study period II

brief_summary.textblock:
Despite numerous studies of meal components in humans, little is still known about how
      different meals influence on metabolism. The purpose of this study is to a gain knowledge of
      how a balanced test meal with either lean seafood (example:cod) or meat as the main protein
      source will:

        1. affect the postprandial metabolism acutely (test-meal at beginning of the study)

        2. affect the postprandial metabolism after 4 weeks controlled intervention (test meal at
           end of intervention period)

        3. affect gut microbiota composition

clinical_study.brief_title: Lean Seafood Intake and Postprandial Metabolism

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  18-65 years of age

          -  Caucasian

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Smoking

          -  Diabetes

          -  Hysterectomy

          -  Abnormal bleeding last 6 months

          -  Use of medication that affects lipid and glucose metabolism

          -  Large (>10%) alteration in body-weight the last 6 months

          -  Chronic, metabolic or acute disease or major surgery within last 3 months

          -  Dietary incompatibility with calcium supplementation and/ or seafood consumption
             (allergy, intolerance, dislike)

facility.name: National Institute of Nutrition and Seafood Research

clinical_study.official_title: Ability of a Lean Seafood Diet to Modulate Postprandial Metabolism in Human-beings - a Controlled Intervention Study With Cross-over Design

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.source: National Institute of Nutrition and Seafood Research, Norway

lead_sponsor.agency: National Institute of Nutrition and Seafood Research, Norway

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
